answers: Bracero program <American History, JP and AK><ed. AH>
parts: Name this man, who co-founded the United Farm Workers of America after a grape-growers strike in Delano, California.
This activist co-founded the UFW with Chávez and coined the phrase “Sì, se puede,” which would later be translated and used during the 2008 election by Barack Obama.
Huerta’s activism also included supporting the repeal of this program by which the United States imported manual laborers from Mexico.

answers: Edward FitzGerald <Short Fiction/Other, OC><ed. OC and AB>
parts: Name this Edwardian author of many mischievous and often gruesome short stories, including “Sredni Vashtar” and “The Open Window.”

Saki’s pen name derives from the “Eternal Saki,” a cupbearer from this series of quatrains by Omar Khayyam. A section in this work praises “a book of verses underneath the bough, a jug of wine, a loaf of bread – and thou.”
The Rubaiyat was given its name by this 19th Century English poet, whose translation of the work begins with the command “Wake!”

answers: square root [accept to the ½ power]
parts: Name this quantity, which is the extent to which a substance can dissolve into another substance. It can be quantified through its namesake product constant.
For sodium chloride, or any other diatomic salt, the molar solubility is this operation on the solubility product constant.
Antimony bonded to six atoms of this element is soluble. Xenon’s bonding ability was first demonstrated through its bonds to 6 of this element and platinum.

answers: Sargon the Great [accept Sargon of Akkad or Sargon I; prompt on Sargon]
Elam <Other History, AK and JP><ed. AH>
parts: Name this man who created the first known postal system in the world after conquering much of Sumer as the ruler of the Akkadian Empire.
Sargon the Great either conquered or founded this city on the Euphrates. This city, known for its famous “hanging gardens,” was once given a famous law code by Hammurabi.
According to the Chronicle of Early Kings, Sargon defeated an attempted invasion by four “great” generals from this polity, which was led by the King of Awan.

answers: Funen [accept Fyn] <Geography, AK><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: Name this peninsula that comprises most of Denmark’s land. This peninsula is separated from Sweden by the Kattegat Bay.
This capital of Denmark is not located on the Jutland Peninsula, but is instead on Zealand Island. It is connected to the Swedish city of Malmö by the Øresund Bridge.
The Little Belt separates Denmark from this Danish island that contains the city of Odense. This island was the birthplace of Hans Christian Andersen.

answers: Matisse’s studio [accept atelier; prompt on descriptive answers like “Matisse’s room”] <Visual Arts, AH><ed. OC>
parts: Name this Fauvist painter of Bonheur de Vivre and The Dance.
After his Fauvist period, Matisse shocked the French Public and the attendees of the Armory Show of 1913 with a “blue” depiction of one of these subjects, which is also owned by the BMA.
Despite the scale of the BMA’s collection, it is MoMA that owns Matisse’s iconic “red” depiction of this space, which features many of his earlier paintings hung up on the walls.

answers: leap day [accept February 29th] <Other Fine Arts, KLu><ed. NR>
parts: Name this character, whose real name is Stanley. In a notable patter song, he has “information vegetable, animal and mineral.”
“I Am the Very Model of a Modern Major-General” appears in this Gilbert and Sullivan opera. In this opera, Frederic falls in love with Mabel, the Major-General’s daughter.
In Pirates of Penzance, Frederic’s marriage to Mabel and his release from indentured servitude is jeopardized when the Pirate King realizes Frederic was born on this specific day.

answers: Pearl S. Buck <Non-epic Poetry, OC><ed. OC>
parts: Name this very short poem which reads in its entirety: “The apparition of these faces in the crowd; / Petals on a wet, black, bough.”
“In a Station of the Metro” was written by Ezra Pound, who found inspiration in Japanese art as well as poems from this country, such as those written by Tang Dynasty poet Du Fu.
This novelist drew on her experiences living in China to write Dragon Seed and The Good Earth, for which she became the first American woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.

answers: circumambulation [accept descriptions involving walking around or circling something]
parts: All Muslims who are physically and financially able are expected to carry out this action at least once in their lifetimes.

Description acceptable. During the Hajj, Muslims perform the Tawaf ritual in which they take this action with respect to the Kaaba seven times. In Hinduism, this action is described by the words Parikrama and Pradakshina.
In contrast to the Hajj, this minor form of pilgrimage to Mecca can be undertaken at any time of the year and can be completed in just a few hours.

answers: Soviet Union [accept Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; do not accept or prompt on “Russia”]
offering All Day Breakfast [accept answers involving offering breakfast the entire day] <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, KLu><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: This McDonald’s product is available for a limited time and at certain locations. This product is a barbecue pork sandwich with onions and pickles.
One ill-fated advertising campaign offered free food if the U.S. won medals at the 1984 Olympics. When this country boycotted the games, the Americans won so many that some locations ran out of food.

Description acceptable. In 2015, McDonald’s undertook this action in all of its U.S. stores. This action required some stores to install new grills and toasters and concerned products including the McGriddle and Sausage Burrito.
Name this dictator of the Philippines who ordered the assassination of political opponent Benigno Aquino. He was overthrown by the People Power Revolution.
This is the collective name given to the group of powerful advisors to Marcos. Its origin comes from a story where each of the advisors allegedly received a namesake watch from Marcos.
Marcos’ wife, Imelda, lived a lavish lifestyle, supposedly owning over 7,000 pairs of these objects. These objects are now housed in a museum in Marikina.

answers: heat capacity [or molar heat capacity, accept molar specific heat, do not accept or prompt on “specific heat” or “specific heat capacity”]
parts: Name this quantity, which describes the ratio between the amount of energy added to the temperature change in the heating of a substance. It is not defined per unit mass of the substance.
The isochoric molar heat capacity of an ideal gas is directly proportional to this quantity by the equipartition theorem. It is three for a monatomic ideal gas.

Heat capacity is often reported in terms of joules per this SI base temperature unit. Absolute zero is zero degrees on this temperature scale, which is interchangeable with Celsius by subtracting 273.15 degrees.

answers: The Profession of Faith of a Savoyard Vicar <Philosophy, DY><ed. AH>
parts: Name this five-part treatise which describes the education of an ideal citizen. It was published a year after the author’s novel Julie, or the New Heloise.
Name this Genevan author of Émile who also penned The Social Contract.
Émile was banned and publicly burned due to a section titled for one of these ecclesiastical representatives, a bishop’s deputy.

answers: Gem of the Ocean <Drama, AK><ed. OC>
parts: Name this play in which former baseball player Troy Maxson is reluctant to let his son, Cory, accept a football scholarship.
Fences is part of the “Pittsburgh Cycle,” a collection of plays by this American author of The Piano Lesson.

This first installment in the “Pittsburgh Cycle” recounts Citizen Barlow’s spiritual journey to the City of Bones with the help of Aunt Ester. In this play, a policeman named Caesar shoots a former slave named Solly Two Kings.

answers: P vs NP [accept descriptions like “Does P equal NP?”] <Other Science, DY><ed. KLei>
parts: One potential example of a one-way function is the discrete form of this function modulo a prime number p. The ElGamal encryption algorithm is based on this function.

Finding the product of two primes p and q is easy, but performing this operation to break the product back into its divisors p and q cannot be done quickly, making it another candidate for a one-way function.

Proving the existence of one-way functions would resolve this Millenium Prize problem which asks whether a problem must also be be solvable in polynomial time if its solution can be verified in polynomial time.
Name this James Joyce work, ending with a soliloquy delivered in eight massive sentences. This novel focuses on Stephen Dedalus and Leopold and Molly Bloom.

Joyce’s final work is this confusing novel that begins “riverrun, past Eve and Adam’s…” Though plot summaries vary, it is agreed that the novel focuses on Anna Livia Plurabelle and Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker.
Joyce also wrote the collection Dubliners, which includes this story about a girl who attempts to escape her father by going to Buenos Aires with Frank.

answers: Ustashe [accept Ustasha or Croatian Revolutionary Movement]
Marshall Joseph Brozovich Tito <European History, AK><ed. AH>
parts: Name this former socialist federation that was formed after the deposition of King Peter II. This state’s breakup led created countries such as Croatia, Serbia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Much of the ethnic strife of the 90s dates back to the atrocities of this Croatian ultranationalist organization formed by Ante Pavelić that cooperated with the Nazis in WWII.
This principle leader of Yugoslavia executed Ustasha members on sight while leading Partisans in WWII. He founded the Non-Aligned Movement with Nehru.

answers: Marche Slave [accept Slavonic March or Serbo-Russian March]
Symphony No. 6 in B minor [accept Symphony “Pathétique”] <Auditory Art, OC><ed. OC>
parts: Name this Tchaikovsky composition that employs bells and cannons in its final section and quotes the national anthem “God Save the Tsar.” This orchestral piece commemorates Russia’s defeat of Napoleon in the title year.
Tchaikovsky’s 1812 Overture is often performed with this more solemn piece that also quotes “God Save the Tsar.” This piece celebrates the wounded veterans of the Serbo-Turkish War.

Tchaikovsky was also a composer of symphonies, including this one, his final and darkest. This symphony’s score calls for a then-unprecedented dynamic marking of six p’s and a “limping waltz” in 5/4 time.
A crescent named for this color marks the future dorsal side of the embryo.
The gray crescent is then bisected by the first of these divisions, which can be meroblastic or, in the case of frogs, holoblastic. Its “furrow” is an indentation that forms during cytokinesis.

Meroblastic cleavage occurs in organisms in which the volume of this stuff is large. During gastrulation, the blastopore surrounds a plug of cells filled with this substance. This portion of the egg contains stored nutrients.

answers: singing [accept reasonable equivalents, prompt on music] <Mythology, AH><ed. OC>
parts: This woman boasted that her artistic talent was superior to Athena. In some versions of the myth, she is turned into a spider after defeating the goddess in a weaving contest; in others, it is because her tapestry makes fun of Zeus.
This daughter of Tantalus boasted that she had more children than Leto, which led to the slaughter of her seven sons and seven daughters by the arrows of Apollo and Artemis.
The Pierides unwisely decided to challenge the Muses to a contest in this activity before being trounced by Calliope, the eldest Muse and mother of Orpheus.
